newsitem.title: FRANCE: French stocks hit by profit-taking, close off lows.
newsitem.headline: French stocks hit by profit-taking, close off lows.

text.p: French stocks fell on Monday on profit-taking on the bourse's 1.6 percent rise last week, but traders said sentiment remained positive and they expected the market to resume its advance after a brief pause.
The blue-chip CAC-40 index closed down 11.52 points, or 0.51 percent, at 2,228.81, while the CAC-40 November futures contract fell 11 points to 2,231.
"The market needed to catch its breath," said a trader, but he added that the mood remained bullish.
Volume was 5.7 billion francs, swollen by active trading in insurance merger partners Axa and UAP.
Axa and UAP fell 1.53 percent and 0.22 percent, respectively, on heavy selling by U.S. funds, brokers said.

They said the selling was probably spurred by U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission rules which do not recognise the "certificates of guaranteed value" offered by Axa as part of the complex share swap agreement announced last week. It entails an exchange of four Axa shares plus four certificates -- guaranteeing a minimum price -- for 10 UAP shares.
Shares in Suez fell 1.38 percent to 221 francs. A broker said its move to sell four billion francs in property loans suggests its real estate problems have not been solved.
Shares in textile firm DMC fell 7.11 percent on continuing disappointment with a 14 percent drop in its nine-month sales and loss forecast for the year.
The share has lost more than 10 percent since announcing its lower nine-month sales on Thursday and forecasting a full-year loss of around 550 million francs in a newspaper interview on Friday.

Euro Disney rallied 7.51 percent ahead of its full-year results on Tuesday morning. Analysts expect a rise in net profit for the year ended on September 30 to between 160 million and 220 million francs. Excluding exceptionals, analysts expect a profit between 100 million and 140 million francs.
